think about the sea ISO meetings that I've been in over the years as part of
Symantec has been thousands of CISOs that I've met and there's some key differences in those conversations that
happened maybe even just five years ago and how they go now so five seven years or so ago the
average CIO so conversation about security and cloud went a little like this my CIO would like to realize the
cost benefits of moving to the cloud so please make sure that we can secure that
information so that we can do it's kind of a permission idea this idea
that we would wait to move to the cloud until security was ready so you fast
forward five years or so to today and I can tell you those CIS Oh conversations
are completely turn the other way around so that the reality of a security team
these days are not faced with how do we secure it so we can do it it's more like
well we did it or we're in the middle of it how do we make sure that we finish strong how do we make sure that we're
building security into it as we go and the pressure on them is not just coming from a CIO perspective although it
usually starts in terms of realizing cost savings but it's also about agility
right the promise of the cloud as a competitive advantage the board of directors of these organizations are
mandating sort of three-year projects to get to cloud as fast as possible and it's a business requirement now not just
a cost savings requirement so if you think from a CIS o-- standpoint you know there their challenge is pretty
significant given the rate of change in the rate of cloud adoption that we see relative to the advancements in the
security field so whereas in the past the security strategy might have been built around this idea that you have
well managed networks and data centers and endpoints the security strategy of today needs to count for ubiquitous
access to your data anywhere at all times so what's interesting too in that context about those seaso conversations
years ago is that you know customers often thought of things like mobility and cloud as different things they were
looking at security problems of iPad tablet type devices versus moving to a
public cloud vendor and I think what they see today is it's really all the same aspect of the same thing in that
what's the value of cloud if you can't connect to it from anything what's the value of a device if you can't deliver
on that promise of ubiquitous access anywhere from any device you need both so the security challenge becomes not a
point product type solution where you're going to buy Symantec Cloud Security 1.2
and that's better than 1.0 and you'll sort of integrate on there and in the cloud security problem is solved
what it means now is this is an ecosystem problem so it's not a point product problem it's an ecosystem
problem so we've put together a platform and you can hear more about this in the
booth the icd platform that focuses on delivering security at a cloud ecosystem
level so you have to secure the end points you have to secure the networks that connect those endpoints to cloud
you have to secure cloud applications from a SAS perspective you have to
secure messaging and security means that you're able to provide core functionality across all those control

kinds of ideas information protection so understanding what is the content and
context of the data that your applications and users are moving around the secret system and and ultimately how

out and go find or get the information that is most security relevant LCP

so now instead of an analyst team having to manually use a simple to sort of

the system kind of follows the same path specific to cloud specific to AWS you
know here's how we have extended those capabilities to be cloud native so the first thing we run into is

built a series of collectors for both Symantec and third-party security SAS
offerings so one of the things we would see in a cloud migration model is that
while people lift and shift a lot of their capabilities they also look to
leverage the SAS version of whatever the on-prem product might be so eliminate

securing endpoints leuco brought in a strong network capability as well as
this Casbah offering the Cosby offering is interesting for cloud as well as for
how we consume the alerts in that it allows us to go far beyond what you
could normally detect in the log kaz be offerings for example can detect shadow
IT use so this idea that you've got users in the environment and they're using box or Dropbox or whatever types

that integration then finally but perhaps the most important we built cloud native collector capabilities for
AWS platform so this actually works kind of in two different ways so one is a
consumer of AWS alerts so things detected already by AWS security
services so here you can think of things like guard duty or a cloud watch as well

doing this for a while you know we've been in the top right of the Gartner Quadrant for about fourteen years with
this offering you know with the cloud adoption and the expansion of our capabilities into a sort of full managed
cloud defense kind of model you know what you can immediately then see is there's a scale problem brewing right so
we're actually projecting that the amount of data that will ingest into AWS is over doubling year on you so right
now we're at about 200 billion events per day that we ingest and I think
what's most interesting about that is not actually the volume of ingestion I think if you've you know attended the

not that complicated you know until your credit card runs out you could anybody can sort of push large
volumes of data into an s3 bucket and call it Big Data right I think what's
interesting about it is the connection between scale and security so there's a
well known breach that's been in the media as a global shipping company and what was said there is that the time
between the malware infecting the first machine and the global operation being
stopped was seven seconds seven seconds so when I think about cloud I think
about scale and I that into security latency in the system
is a security issue we're essentially in a race condition with attackers can we
find them and stop them before they can actually have impact to the organization knowing that it can now happen in
seconds so you know scale in AWS latency and big
complicated systems like this it's not just about operational efficiency or improving the customer experience with
the platform it's actually a security issue so when we thought about this we said okay a lifting shift approach has
some benefit I mean we can move our platform into AWS and sort of turn on Auto scale we would see some benefits
from that for sure though with that added security dimension it's not good
enough so we decided at the end of the day that in addition to adopting AWS as
our sort of backbone in general for this offering that we needed to roll up our sleeves and do the hard work of
completely re platforming some of the components of the system to use the AWS
server less components and we chose the serverless component stack not just
because of sort of the ease of you know
adopting AWS to provide better security outcomes but also then because our engineering teams can reallocate their
efforts away from managing servers and more on the analytic side which is ultimately what the customers pay us for
so the server lists concept is critical for us to realize the security benefits
of the scale focus as we as we did this work so I'm going to talk you through some of the things we did there so this
is a 300 level session so I will assume you know what s3 is and how great it is and all that sort of thing so obviously
s3 it becomes our storage environment it provides a durable and scalable approach
with things like auto scale as well as being able to age data off automatically into glacier at certain points and all
that so as I'm sure you would imagine we're using s3 and replacing our storage
arrays you know and I can remember and some of the guys in the room here on our team remember this very well you know the
idea before is you had to predict what your storage needs were going to be placed an order with a vendor or wait for the array to arrive get it rack and
all that kind of jazz and then hope that you got it right in terms of predicting the data load you were going to need and
then if you see the the prior slide where we're over doubling the amount of data and it's turning into an X
exponential curve you essentially end up in this continuous buying of storage arrays and there are limitations to the
walls of the data center right so s3 has been a great change I think what's more
interesting about it than just the fact we use s3 in this sock technology platform is some of the stuff we do
around it to ultimately feed the analytics pipeline in a way that reduces
that latency I talked about as being a security issue so our LCP appliance when it sends data
up into our system there's sort of three levers that it waits for there's either
a number of rows or log lines queuing up there's the file size of the log file
queuing up or there's the amount of time gone by and once it hits the maximum threshold in one of those dimensions
wraps up the file and sends it up into the system when it lands in s3 with fire
lambda functions and the lambda functions do a couple things one thing they do is they buffer the incoming
files they wait for it to hit an optimal size that we know that downstream services like redshift work best with
and then they write out a new file and parquet floor mat and I'll get to it on the next slide why parquet and why that
is such an important decision the second thing those lambda those
lambda fires do is they create an entry in dynamodb about metadata about what
the log source is where it's coming from those sorts of things and that becomes important when we look at downstream
consumption again of things like redshift and Athena which I'll describe
a bit more in the next slide hope you think about scale again and what's actually happening here at this level of
ingestion on average we've got about 400 lambdas firing every second so I mean
that that's a significant technology advantage that the AWS platform is able
to provide something that can work in that way so 400 a second it's about 35
million a day it actually peaks at around 100 million lambdas firing every day just to support this concept of
full-scale global log ingestion across a potentially unlimited number of sources
in a way that minimizes latency for security benefit right that's a massive achievement the other thing that happens
here is its really our fan-out mechanism so once the data arrives as an entry in DynamoDB that describes the the metadata
about what was uploaded we essentially then fan-out to downstream consumers
typically these are analytics processes so in the case of streaming analytics which usually drives a lot of the
machine learning components of our system things like Apache storm and
spark maintain pointers in a Kinesis data stream so that's how the analytic
systems are able to consume directly from what gets put in s3 for sort of
real-time or the advanced analytical use cases for a batch analytics so these are
security analytics that happen at some interval or when some condition is true typically the batch analytics will
leverage two DynamoDB directly to understand what's being put into the system and decide if it's time for them
to act another way that we fan out the data is through SNS so we're using SNS to enable
downstream applications in ec2 to subscribe to specific topics so when
they get a notification of that topic they can then take action probably the most interesting application in ec2 that
uses the SNS topics is our log anonymizer so if you think about one of
the mean values of semantics doing this the fact that we have the sock technology platform the services and
their technologies is we're able to take customer log data remove the customer
specific information from it and then combine it upstream with product telemetry and security intelligence in
that ICD platform for R&D purposes so the ability to you know invent or design
new types of security analytics to find these at advanced attack actors becomes
exponentially easier and more effective the richer the set of data that you have so the anonymization of the customer
data and our MSS service for example allows allows us to do some innovative R&D now finally on the server list
component side you've got this idea for access query and search capabilities
we're using a combination of Athena redshift and redshift spectrum depending on the different use cases which
obviously from a scale perspective gives us the idea with redshift especially that you can scale up and down your
search capability as the query low exchange so I asked the team you know this is as fast as I can do it I asked
the team you know with with that work being done you know what are the basic ABC's that anyone attending this session
should walk out with right what are the sort of things that if we would have been clear on at the start of this would
have made it easier or better so that we could share that with you to avoid similar mistakes or help you onboard
into a similar approach so the first one is around that Park a file format so
this is the idea that file types matter a lot in these kind of workloads where 7
seconds is a big deal from a security perspective so for us we chose Park Hae because the
combination of parquet and redshift allows us to realize the benefits of a columnar type of database structure so
if we we looked at the the queries in our system and said you know a good chunk of the queries that are important
a benefit from comp columnar type of approaches right so for example how many
times have we ever seen this IP you know that that's a type of thing where you don't need to go over every row to look
for that IP and condition you should just be able to do that in the column so in our testing using Parque
specifically as a file format with redshift gives the best results so the recommendation here is to really you
know understand the query load that you have from your users and your applications evaluate the different file
formats that are out there and test to make sure that the right combination of
consumer of your data and how you're writing it to disk in a particular format gives you the right results the
second one is this idea of scale through creating one big system or many small
systems so I think there's a tendency when you think of big data systems to think of one big one you know you create
this big data pond and then it continues to grow and it continues to grow and you scale by growing that one thing or is
that there are some use cases where it's actually better to make many many small things so in our example in a redshift
spectrum for example it has a 15 limit on concurrent queries so our our system
sort of runs normally at about 50 to 75 concurrent queries so a limit of 15 is
not going to fly so rather than build one big redshift cluster with that
limitation we worked directly with Amazon pretty good partnership and great work with the AWS team so to implement a
system where we use many small redshift clusters behind a load balancer and in that way we're able to get around that concurrency limitation so that's the
second recommendation is you know don't think about scale in terms of making one huge thing but sometimes it's better to
make many small things and then finally there's a notion of flexibility so in a
legacy system if we had a downstream consumer of data an analytic engine for
example that expected data in a certain way we would rewrite the data we would copy it and in some cases we're copying
the same data four or five times in the data center for different use cases obviously that's expensive in terms of
storage but it also increases latency right which we said was the problem from
a security standpoint so by using metadata about our logs in
we can leverage things like AWS glue and the glue catalog concept such that
services like Athena and redshift know how to use that data without having to rewrite it so whether they need to see
it by customer or by date or time or whatever that metadata exists in the glue catalog and the services can use
them directly so obviously there's a lot of cost and efficiency for us in approaching it that way so that ends the
kind of first topic around scale and the importance of scale and some of the things that we've been up to you as
relates to using AWS server less components I did I certainly didn't do

compares to other form factors so on an on-prem environment you know
infrastructure change is an anomaly that's interesting from a security standpoint you might expect a sort of

10 new server spun up in a data center and instead of talking to an IP that they hadn't talked to you before that

think you know most of the customers that we talked to are sort of far away from realizing an infrastructure as code

have to think about security in that context if not already so what you see
in the cloud environment is infrastructure is dynamic it would actually make sense if there were 10 new servers that's blown up and then you

right since every everything that happens within a cloud infrastructure happens under the context of a user

semantics poor business so we invest a lot of time money resources into building analytical systems machine

the researchers on my team so Stan Kiefer and Brian Varner how would how
would a normal organization do this you know is there and what much like the infrastructure that we looked at the AWS
server 'less components to make it easier on us how would your average customer use these server list
components to detect these kinds of new ripples or new behavioral anomalies for
user accounts so here's what they came up with so the first thing I'll just build this out for you in the interest
of time first thing we did was we established a sort of new baseline process around Identity and Access
Management so we suck out a customer's cloud trail logs we have cloud watch
rules which essentially filter out anything that's not a user action we
fire a lambda function which parses that data and then stores it in a dynamo DB
instance so it's storing what's the role what's the user what action did that user take and then sort of metadata
around the frequency and an amount of times that this happens so this establishes a sort of ongoing baseline
you know DynamoDB is saying this is what's normal in my environment so then
we work with the guard duty team such that when guard duty finds this particular event they call it an unknown
ASN collar it's basically a type of security detection that says this user account is accessing the system from a
network or IP that it has not before or doesn't normally so we use the guard
duty alert as the catalyst as the catalyst so from there we have cloud
watch rules which take out you know strip out everything except those ASN
unusable ASM collar events we have a lambda function that then checks against the DynamoDB and says is this normal so
you have the first wave of detection which is from guard duty saying is it is it normal to access this resource from
this particular network and then we're adding a second layer on top of it which says and is this a normal action for
this user account is it anomalous the third layer we add on it is intelligence
in Richmond so we have our deep side data feeds where we're able to say are any of the IPS or other indicators in
these guard duty events known to be associated with malicious attack actors obviously if there are if these three
security components add up you have a serious issue so in that sense we use all three components we'll alert on it
but we can sort of dynamically prioritize based on a weighting between the three and obviously then you know it
could be sent as findings to your sim or Splunk or you know one of our service
offerings so this is actually kind of simple you know outside of the lambda
functions that we wrote which are you know Python scripts that I can share you know these are off-the-shelf
AWS components I took to two guys on my team about a week and they got some really interesting results out of it so
first they were using a open source JavaScript library d3.js to kind of provide a visualization this is a
snippet of it of what the normal user account access was like and I think it
really hits home to expect that a sock analyst can look at something like that and say oh yeah that dot that one's the
problem so guard duty guard duty does a good job of that for us right so guard duty helps narrow it down and say hey
this user action is happening from a network or an IP that it doesn't
normally happen from so the the enrichment process that I described after that takes the next level so again
with d3.js were sort of visualized you know what are the specific actions that that user was taking and then based on
our threat intelligence and the signatures that we put into that dynamodb instance we categorize you know
which of these actions were benign or potentially malicious and we don't have time for me to go through the entire
story but within minutes of the team putting this system up we found which is
essentially Bitcoin mining if you follow through that story that is illustrated there you know somebody got into the
system figured out what role they have created a different user account and then use it ultimately spin up a bunch
of cryptocurrency mining so the final
leg for my time with you is really to then describe the importance of being
